channel.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
channel.description:
For like the millionth time this year already, someone asked in IRC what a good bot was... and the answer, as usual was "none".
But we have loads of little hobbyist bots (unless everyones given up, pussies?) and a few major players, RSBot etc.
So why aren't they good?
(I'm staying impartial for the interests of the thread, I want to know what everyone else thinks makes a good bot and why RSBot isn't it.)

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:35, topic:378167”][quote author=packersfa52 link=topic=474049.msg3474566#msg3474566 date=1295573673]
Scriptability isn’t a proper factor to base the bot off of because the capabilities of one person may be able to code like prod while others would think it’s garbage.
[/quote]

All the more reason to not require your users to be able to code like a pro, surely[/quote]That

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @packersfa52 packersfa52
item.description:
@packersfa52 wrote:

What makes a good bot…? A good developer. I’d prefer a bot by a well known person with a decent work ethic then say someone who drops the ball continuously.

Scriptability isn’t a proper factor to base the bot off of because the capabilities of one person may be able to code like prod while others would think it’s garbage. I’d say Antirandoms, Usablity, AI talking[Haven’t seen yet], and I guess functions of the bot itself. A good bot isn’t limited to those just listed, just my personal would be favorite bot.

Read full topic

@xEnt wrote:

bring back Zetabot u fgt johan

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @Tekk123 Tekk
item.description:
@Tekk123 wrote:

Existing bots all have a general level of mediocrity because a) most bots that random people create never get to a release (People can’t maintain their updaters) and b) most bots that are released are just generic clones of prior, existing bots.

That being said, I’d be interested in seeing a bot that breaks out of this cycle. Injection and reflection are no longer new and innovative as they were a few years ago. Also, all recent bots I’ve seen only work on the software rendering toolkit in the client because they depend on its usage of the AWT drawing system to ‘hack the canvas’ or whatever.

Any bot that does something different than the other bots out there is a ‘good’ bot in my eyes.

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:

[quote=“Mopman, post:28, topic:378167”]You can still have a “scriptable” bot, you just have to change everyones notion of what a script is.

I can’t believe I’m finding myself seeing Franks point of view[/quote]That. A so called scriptable bot nowadays is no more than a cheap copy of Aryan (which had godawful scripting by the way).

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:26, topic:378167”][quote author=zuppers link=topic=474049.msg3471247#msg3471247 date=1295307060]
If you want the bot to log you out or shutdown when you get stuck or sent to a random, just have it check your area. If your in the area of where the bot is suppose take you stay logged in. If your not in the permitted area then have it log you out. Not that complicated really.
[/quote]

I admit I’m playing a little bit of the devil’s advocate here, but that wouldn’t work with scripts that don’t have a set location to operate in. Like a power miner or woodcutter that should work around ANY rocks or trees.

You can’t take ALL of the responsibility out of the script writer’s hands.[/quote]

Depends if you want a scripted bot. Look how successful RSDemon was.

Although I would prefer a scriptable bot myself, you find it hard for the quality of scripts and event notifiers to be that good. If they were implemented by the dev team and bug fixes etc were submitted by a group of coders who have access to only the api and the source code of the scripts, the quality would be higher.

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

zuppers:

If you want the bot to log you out or shutdown when you get stuck or sent to a random, just have it check your area. If your in the area of where the bot is suppose take you stay logged in. If your not in the permitted area then have it log you out. Not that complicated really.

I admit I’m playing a little bit of the devil’s advocate here, but that wouldn’t work with scripts that don’t have a set location to operate in. Like a power miner or woodcutter that should work around ANY rocks or trees.

You can’t take ALL of the responsibility out of the script writer’s hands.

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:20, topic:378167”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=474049.msg3470499#msg3470499 date=1295257119]
What about scripts that are SUPPOSED to stand in the same spot for more than 2 minutes, fletchers, super-heat, mining addy or rune, etc etc. It should be up to the script to do that kind of thing.
[/quote]

Agreed that it’s not a good way of doing it, but disagreed that it’s up to the script. IMO remove as much responsibility from the hands of the script writer as possible (hi frank!).[/quote]

I agree with that too, I just don’t know how the bot/antirandom etc is supposed to know and adapt to every type of script ever made. Possibly something like Ollie mentioned could work, if flat out nothing was happening for X minutes then maybe you could, but what about a script designed to mine rune ore? You would be standing there doing literally nothing for minutes until it respawned. So surely the script would at minimum need to be able to set a sane timeout level, maybe 2 minutes would be a good default, but don’t impose it on every script.

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @IlikeArrays IlikeArrays
item.description:
@IlikeArrays wrote:

Extend the time to 5 minutes? Also I agree with Mopmans statement.

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

What about scripts that are SUPPOSED to stand in the same spot for more than 2 minutes, fletchers, super-heat, mining addy or rune, etc etc. It should be up to the script to do that kind of thing.

Agreed that it’s not a good way of doing it, but disagreed that it’s up to the script. IMO remove as much responsibility from the hands of the script writer as possible (hi frank!).

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

IlikeArrays:

Kill switch meaning if you stand in the same damn spot for 2 minutes you get logged out. Maybe even make it so the whole application gets shutdown.

What about scripts that are SUPPOSED to stand in the same spot for more than 2 minutes, fletchers, super-heat, mining addy or rune, etc etc. It should be up to the script to do that kind of thing.

Read full topic

item.title: What makes for a _good_ bot?
item.dc:creator: @IlikeArrays IlikeArrays
item.description:
@IlikeArrays wrote:

-Running Multiple Bots
-Easy Script System
-Speed / Performance

-Reliability
I do not want to come back to my computer and see my damn account stuck behind a door. Creating a kill switch for a bot would work well for this. Kill switch meaning if you stand in the same damn spot for 2 minutes you get logged out. Maybe even make it so the whole application gets shutdown.

Read full topic

characterized by tenderness, compassion, and sympathy for people and animals, esp. for the suffering or distressed: humane treatment of horses.
